name: Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)
summary: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is a water-soluble vitamin essential for amino acid metabolism, neurotransmitter synthesis, hemoglobin production, and regulation of homocysteine levels.
description: Vitamin B6 refers to a group of related compounds including pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine, which are converted in the body to the active form pyridoxal 5'-phosphate (PLP). PLP functions as a coenzyme in over 100 enzymatic reactions, especially those involved in amino acid metabolism, neurotransmitter production (such as serotonin, dopamine, GABA), hemoglobin synthesis, and gluconeogenesis. Deficiency may lead to anemia, irritability, depression, confusion, weakened immune function, and in severe cases, seizures. It is sometimes supplemented for premenstrual syndrome (PMS), morning sickness, and mood regulation, though evidence varies.

metadata.natural_source: Poultry, fish, bananas, fortified cereals, potatoes, chickpeas

primary_indications: Treatment and prevention of vitamin B6 deficiency
off_label_uses: Morning sickness in pregnancy (often combined with doxylamine)
monitoring_required: Neurological status if taking high doses long-term

items: Treatment and prevention of vitamin B6 deficiency
Adjunct in pregnancy-related nausea and vomiting

sections.text: Vitamin B6 (as pyridoxal 5'-phosphate) serves as a coenzyme in numerous enzymatic reactions, especially those involved in amino acid metabolism, neurotransmitter synthesis (serotonin, dopamine, GABA), hemoglobin formation, gluconeogenesis, and homocysteine metabolism.

adult.clinical: 25–50 mg/day for pregnancy-related nausea; 10–50 mg/day for PMS; up to 100–200 mg/day for certain clinical conditions (e.g., isoniazid therapy, sideroblastic anemia)

sections.text: Deficiency symptoms improve within days to weeks of supplementation; neurological recovery may take longer.

common: Generally well tolerated at nutritional doses
serious: Sensory neuropathy (at doses >500 mg/day for prolonged periods)

other: Chronic high-dose use can cause irreversible sensory neuropathy.
Supplementation may be necessary with certain medications (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine, penicillamine).

items.risk: Can cause B6 deficiency and neuropathy
High-dose pyridoxine can reduce levodopa efficacy unless given with carbidopa
items.action: Avoid high-dose supplementation without medical supervision

sections.pregnancy: Safe at recommended dietary intakes; used therapeutically for morning sickness

sections.text: Not required; supplementation may be stopped without tapering.

items: B6 deficiency can be caused by chronic alcohol use, malnutrition, or medications like isoniazid.
Supplementation often included in multivitamins and B-complex formulations.
Active form P5P is sometimes marketed as more bioavailable, though standard pyridoxine is effective.
